content: I'm in Lenawee County, down near the Ohio border. Farming community. It's been a tough few years - input costs are through the roof, fertilizer prices doubled, diesel for the equipment is killing us. We had decent yields this year but the margins are razor thin.
participant_profile: M, 52, Farmer (corn, soybeans), Lenawee County, rural, registered Republican, "used to vote straight ticket"
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for joining this virtual discussion. I want to start by hearing from different parts of the state. What's life like where you live, and what's top of mind for you heading into this election?

content: I'm up in Traverse City. Beautiful area, tourism is our economy. Things are busy in summer but the off-season is brutal. A lot of people here work multiple jobs just to afford housing. Tourists don't realize the locals can barely afford to live here anymore.
participant_profile: F, 38, Retail manager, Traverse City, independent, tourism-dependent economy concerns
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for joining this virtual discussion. I want to start by hearing from different parts of the state. What's life like where you live, and what's top of mind for you heading into this election?

content: Flint here. Where do I start? We're still dealing with the water crisis fallout. I have a six-year-old who was exposed to lead. The infrastructure here is crumbling. Detroit gets all the attention but Flint feels forgotten.
participant_profile: M, 34, Construction foreman, Flint, Genesee County, water crisis survivor, "doesn't trust politicians"
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for joining this virtual discussion. I want to start by hearing from different parts of the state. What's life like where you live, and what's top of mind for you heading into this election?

content: Macomb County, work at the Stellantis plant. The auto industry is going through massive changes right now - EVs, battery tech. My job feels secure for now but who knows in ten years? The whole industry might look different.
participant_profile: M, 47, Auto plant worker (Stellantis), Sterling Heights, UAW member, Macomb County
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for joining this virtual discussion. I want to start by hearing from different parts of the state. What's life like where you live, and what's top of mind for you heading into this election?

content: Saginaw. Used to be a GM town, not so much anymore. Crime has gotten bad. The downtown is struggling. Lot of empty buildings. It feels like the state forgot about us too.
participant_profile: M, 66, Retired police sergeant, Saginaw, Saginaw County, concerned about crime and pension
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for joining this virtual discussion. I want to start by hearing from different parts of the state. What's life like where you live, and what's top of mind for you heading into this election?

content: Midland here. We had catastrophic floods two years ago when the dams failed. Thousands of homes destroyed, including mine. We're still rebuilding. Infrastructure matters when your whole life can wash away overnight.
participant_profile: F, 48, Insurance agent, Midland, Mid-Michigan, flood recovery still affecting area

participant_profile: F, 44, Hospital administrator, Ann Arbor, Democrat but "not reliably so," Washtenaw County
